title: 107_s3105
content: The Act may be cited as the "West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act" and includes a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. Section 319 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases, allowing the Secretary to make grants to States for prevention and control efforts. Grants under this subsection encourage collaboration with local health entities to develop prevention and control programs. Preference may be given to States with a substantial incidence of West Nile Virus or related diseases, or increased risk. Funds from grants are to be used for prevention and control efforts. Funds from grants under this subsection are to be used for developing comprehensive mosquito control plans and programs on vector-borne diseases, including training for a competent workforce. The grant under this subsection aims to develop a competent workforce for local mosquito and vector-borne disease control programs, with requirements for matching funds and limitations on supplanting. Non-Federal contributions must cover at least 50% of costs for the grant, which can be in cash or in kind. Federal funds or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included in the contribution amount. Non-Federal contributions for grants must cover 50% of costs, in cash or in kind, and cannot include Federal funds or services. Grants should supplement, not supplant, State and local funds. The Secretary can waive requirements for a State based on economic conditions. Local involvement is required. The State receiving funds must involve localities in mosquito control plans and ensure 85% of the grant is spent locally for public health improvement. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention can use funds to provide technical assistance to State and local health departments for mosquito control programs and containment of arboviral diseases. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention can allocate funds for technical assistance in developing mosquito abatement guidelines, with a limitation of 20 percent of the appropriated amount for this purpose. The plan will be created in collaboration with health and mosquito control organizations. The plan involves developing guidelines for sustainable mosquito control programs, focusing on identifying new cases of disease and monitoring disease spread in various species. The plan includes monitoring infection in various creatures, providing laboratory support, increasing participation in surveillance systems, conducting educational campaigns, and outlining procedures for mosquito control and health monitoring. The Secretary will evaluate the program established under the West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act and submit a report to Congress within 18 months of enactment, including the results of the evaluation. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 18 months of enactment, evaluating the sustainable mosquito abatement program's progress, guidelines development, and overall costs and benefits. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 and 2004 for control programs related to the West Nile Virus or other arboviruses. This authorization is in addition to existing authorizations under the Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Response Act of 2002. The program established under this subsection will terminate after a certain period. The program established under this subsection will terminate on September 30, 2004, but may be extended for an additional fiscal year based on evaluation. SEC. 249. ARBOVIRUS RESEARCH PROGRAM is added to Part B of title II of the Public Health Service Act. The program will terminate on September 30, 2004, with a possible extension based on evaluation. The President is mandated to enhance research to control insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus, develop rapid screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies. The President is required to enhance research to control insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus and develop rapid screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies through various entities such as the National Institutes of Health, Environmental Protection Agency, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The President is authorized to promote coordination between relevant Federal agencies, private sector, and experts in public health, entomology, arbovirology, and veterinary health. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2003 through 2007.
